Problem, Purpose statements & Research questions
The development of short supply chain is becoming a topic of growing interest among consumers, researchers and public bodies in Europe. More than ever, the resilience of a territory relies in the capacity of becoming less dependant of outlier productors (reference?), whiwh is a elements highligtly identified by the pandemic conditions. However, the evaluation of pertinent sustainable indicators for this short supply networks is one the major topic of discussion in the scientific and practitioners communities. The problem relies in the selection of these â€˜pertinentâ€™ indicators and trade-offs that need to be considered for a holistic evaluation and the scope of the short supply chain. Moreover, depending of the material or product and their technological process associated to, this entakes difficulties in terms of dependance of stakeholders beyond the scope of the short circuit.
The context of this research is the development of a short plastic recycling network for distributing recycling purposes (reference?). The development of the development of distributing recycling approach via additive manufacturing (DRAM) (Fabio A. Cruz Sanchez et al. 2020) is emerging as an interesting topic to propose additoanl cascading loops to certain types plastic waste. More precisely, the use of recycled assets in the printing process chaing of additive manufacturing technology can give add value to wastes to create possible products or scientific equipement a a lower cost than the commercial. In a sense, this apporache could be an operationalization strategy for the development of secondary raw materials, which is one of major pillars in the recycling strategy for the Circular economy in Europe.
Therefore, the main research question is how to evaluate the global sustainability of short supply chains to foster the plastic recycling networks in a local territory?. More precisely, What are the the â€˜pertinentâ€™ qualitative and quantitative indicators to evaluate the local distributed recycling network in terms of revelance of quality and feasibility to obtain appropriate data with local stakeholders? One element to highlight the impact that third-spaces as innovations labs, fablabs and/or makerspace can play an role in order to apporaprio agents of change the development of
The objectives of this research are:
Establish a grid of economical, political, environementa and social indicators.
Define model of stakeholders that can be impacted (positive / negative) for the case of plastic recycling
â€¦
Therefore, the purpose of this research is to set a baseline of sustainable indicators to evaluate a local short supply chain network for distributed recycling. The main perspectives relies in the articulation of means of implementation and means evaluations based sustaianble decision tools for this type of networks.

articles.title: Environmental behaviour & practices
articles.contents:
Contents
Abstract
Rationale
On Circular Economy (CE)
On Theory of planned Behaviour
On Distributed Recycling via Additive Manufacturing

On pro-environmental behaviours



require(DiagrammeR)
require(tidyverse)
require(kableExtra)



Abstract
Master 3: Mise en place de la collecte des bouchonsâ€¯: pourrait Ãªtre analyse sur le comportement des acteurs => quel changement dans ces profils de gensâ€¯? => autre master (identifier ce que Ã§a change chez les gens qui participent ou pas) avec Tatiana et Laure !!! doctorant avec master cÃ´tÃ© Nancy (avec Hakim et Mauricio)
Rationale
Some ideas:
On Circular Economy (CE)
Circular economy decisions are very complex but often the perceptions, attitudes, and personal values of decision makers directly influence organizationsâ€™ strategic actions towards a circular economy. Both active participation of organizations and the role of decision makers are pivotal to implement a circular economy for plastics (Khan et al. 2020).
Identifying and assessing specific barriers associated with the workplace context could be crucial for achieving better employee engagement and a lower ecological footprint for organizations (Yuriev et al. 2020)
Barriers of CE implementation
Khan et al. (2020) identified barriers to deploy CE Plastics in order of importance are as follows. The foremost barrier is that organizations (Entreprises) do not have easy access to recycling facilities. Second, organizations cannot transport plastic waste to recycling facilities. Third, organizations do not have enough space to store plastic waste. Fourth, organizations do not have enough time to sort plastic waste. Fifth, organizations do not have sufficient funds to pursue plastic recycling. Sixth, organizations do not have skilled personnel to sort plastic waste. Seventh, organizations do not have an environmental expert at the management level. Lastly, organizations do not know about potential buyers of plastic waste. These findings imply that prominent barriers are physical factors rather than knowledge. Overall, these findings contribute to the literature on the barriers of a circular economy
On Theory of planned Behaviour
Ajzen (1991) developed Theory of Planned Behaviour (TPB) which is one of the most influencing model for designing behavioral interventions (Yuriev et al. 2020). Therefore, researchers have been increasingly employing the TPB model across various disciplines including environmental science and sustainability management TPB postulates considers three main aspects
Attitude towards behavioral intention,
Subjective Norms (SN), and
Perceived Behavioral Control (PCB),
together they shape behavioral intention as well as actual behavior. To date, TPB has received around 90,000 citations (Yuriev et al. 2020)


{"x":{"diagram":"\ngraph LR\n  A[\"Attitude toward the act (Att)\"]-->D[Behavioural Intention]\n  B[\"Subjective Norm (SN)\"]-->D[Behavioural Intention]\n  C[\"Perceived Behavioural Control (PBC)\"]-->D[Behavioural Intention]\n  D[Behavioural Intention]-->E[Behaviour]\n  C[Perceived Behavioural Control]-.->E[Behaviour]\n  \n  classDef className font-size:20px;\n  class A,B,C,D className;\n"},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}
Theory of planned behavior (TPB) is based on the assumption that some conscious reasoning is involved in the formation of intentions to perform a behavior.
Behavior partly on the control of the individual
Behavior is predicted by attitudinal and normative factors and perceived behavioral control (PBC).
PBC reflects the extent to which the individual feels able to perform the behavior.
Past behavior tends to predict intentions and future behavior
The factors that influenced the past behavior continue to influence the intentions and future behavior, but past behavior does not cause future behavior.


TPB <- 
tribble(
  ~Variable, ~Definition, ~Definition.recycling,
  "Attitude", 
    "Attitude toward the behavior and refers to the degree to which a person has a favorable or unfavorable evaluation or appraisal of the behavior in question",
      "The extent to which plastic recycling is valued by people, whether positive or negative",
  
  "Subjective Norms",
   "The perceived social pressure to perform or not to perform the behavior",
      "The extent to which people are influenced by perceived norms of plastic recycling in their  surroundings",
      
  "Perceived Behavioral Control (PCB)",   
    "The perceived ease or difficulty of performing the behavior and it is assumed to reflect past experience as well as anticipated impediments and obstacles", 
        "the perceived power (and knowledge) of people to implement plastic recycling",
  
  "Behavioral intention",   
    "They are indications of how hard people are willing to try, of how much of an effort they are planning to exert, in order to perform the behavior",
    "A perceived likelihood or subjective probability of decision makers that they will implement plastic recycling in their organizations",
  
  
  "Behaviour", 
    " ",
      "The extent to which organizations have implemented best practices of plastic recycling"
)





kbl(TPB) %>%
  kable_paper(full_width = F)



Variable


Definition


Definition.recycling


Attitude


Attitude toward the behavior and refers to the degree to which a person has a favorable or unfavorable evaluation or appraisal of the behavior in question


The extent to which plastic recycling is valued by people, whether positive or negative


Subjective Norms


The perceived social pressure to perform or not to perform the behavior


The extent to which people are influenced by perceived norms of plastic recycling in their surroundings


Perceived Behavioral Control (PCB)


The perceived ease or difficulty of performing the behavior and it is assumed to reflect past experience as well as anticipated impediments and obstacles


the perceived power (and knowledge) of people to implement plastic recycling


Behavioral intention


They are indications of how hard people are willing to try, of how much of an effort they are planning to exert, in order to perform the behavior


A perceived likelihood or subjective probability of decision makers that they will implement plastic recycling in their organizations


Behaviour




The extent to which organizations have implemented best practices of plastic recycling


On Distributed Recycling via Additive Manufacturing
The centralized schemes is the current paradigm for recycling concerns large majority of research on recycling behaviour comes within the scope of municipal waste management schemes.
Centralized recycling schemes have been criticized for inducing much waste transportation, which limits the ecological and economic benefits of recycling, especially in low density areas. Therefore, in order to mitigate CO2 emissions and financial costs of transporting, the concept of distributed recycling emerged. Distributed recycling schemes are characterized by decentralized plastic waste collection, sorting and transformation. It includes in-house recycling, or recycling in local small-scale recycling networks, be it in a community, a company, or a public organisation. If understandings of distributed recycling regarding the decentralisation level differs, scholars agree on its potential for reducing gas emissions from waste collection and creating groundbreaking alternative value chains to the established raw-resources based manufacturing .
For Kreiger (2014), distributed recycling schemes could bring benefits in any economic context, independently of development levels. In the present study, the technology enabling recycling in a distributed recycling scheme is 3D printing, which we call distributed recycling via additive manufacturing (DRAM). A large variety of goods can be produced recycling plastic with 3D technology. Therefore, we believe DRAM has the potential for enhancing the circular economy approach and â€œclose the loop.â€
On pro-environmental behaviours
Yuriev et al. (2020) identified nine systematic literature reviews on pro-environmental behaviors (Li et al., 2019; Lo et al., 2012; Koop et al., 2019; Staddon et al., 2016; Varotto and Spagnolli, 2017; Inoue and Alfaro-Barrantes, 2015; Francoeur et al., 2019; Norton et al., 2015; Yuriev et al., 2018). These are the only existing systematic literature reviews from the last 10 years that covered various individual environmental actions. Having

Positionnement stratÃ©gique du projet
Dans un contexte de consommation mondiale croissante et de pression accrue sur les ressources, qui plus est, celles dÃ©diÃ©es Ã  la survie de lâ€™espÃ¨ce humaine, il est urgent de dissocier la croissance Ã©conomique de lâ€™utilisation de ces derniÃ¨res. Contenu scientifique
Le concept dâ€™Ã©conomie circulaire (EC) est un Ã©lÃ©ment central pour promouvoir un modÃ¨le durable, rÃ©gÃ©nÃ©rateur et inclusif qui peut aider de maniÃ¨re significative nos Ã©conomies Ã  se rÃ©concilier avec les limites et les frontiÃ¨res de notre planÃ¨te en restaurant les systÃ¨mes naturels, en rÃ©duisant les Ã©missions de GES (gaz Ã  effet de serre), et en minimisant la perte de capital naturel et de biodiversitÃ©. Le fonctionnement en circuit court est lâ€™un des piliers pour rendre les opÃ©rations dâ€™une filiÃ¨re plus efficaces et rationnelles, tout en crÃ©ant de la valeur locale (Capasso et al., 2019). Cependant son opÃ©rationnalisation nÃ©cessite des prises de dÃ©cision qui sâ€™avÃ¨rent difficiles, car elles challengent le paradigme actuel des activitÃ©s industrielles, centrÃ©es principalement sur lâ€™Ã©valuation technico-Ã©conomiques et, encore trop peu et trop rÃ©cemment sur des considÃ©rations environnementales. En effet, la vision traditionnelle reste prÃ©gnante bien que limitÃ©e car elle ne considÃ¨re pas systÃ©matiquement lâ€™ensemble des impacts dâ€™une activitÃ© sur les Ã©cosystÃ¨mes.
Comme dÃ©montrÃ© par les travaux rÃ©alisÃ©s depuis 2001 par le CREIDD sur les thÃ©matiques de lâ€™Ã©cologie industrielle, lâ€™Ã©co-conception, lâ€™analyse de cycle de vie et lâ€™Ã©valuation des risques environnementaux, la comprÃ©hension des mÃ©canismes de transition industrielle en incluant des dimensions de durabilitÃ©, sont fondamentaux. De mÃªme, ils ont montrÃ© lâ€™importance dâ€™une vision intÃ©grÃ©e pour la conception des systÃ¨mes industriels-territoires (Bruel et al., 2019, 2016, 2014; Troussier et al., 2017; Vadoudi et al., 2015, 2014). Plus rÃ©cemment, des travaux ont montrÃ© que le rapprochement de lâ€™Ã©cologie industrielle et de lâ€™Ã©conomie Ã©cologique peut Ãªtre un moyen dâ€™aller au-delÃ  de lâ€™Ã©tude physique des flux de matiÃ¨re et dâ€™Ã©nergie (Bruel et al., 2016). En particulier dans ce projet on sâ€™intÃ©ressera Ã  la quantification et prise en compte des services rendus par une organisation industrielle Ã  son territoire (espace naturel, humain et social). Ceci soulÃ¨ve la question des externalitÃ©s environnementales et plus particuliÃ¨rement des services Ã©cosystÃ©miques rendus.
Les services Ã©cosystÃ©miques ont Ã©tÃ© dÃ©finis par (De Groot et al., 2002) comme la capacitÃ© des processus et des constituants de la nature Ã  fournir des biens et services qui rÃ©pondent aux besoins humains, directement ou indirectement. Ces biens et services sont gÃ©nÃ©ralement associÃ©s Ã  des fonctions de rÃ©gulation, des fonctions dâ€™habitat, des fonctions de production et des fonctions dâ€™information. Plus prÃ©cisÃ©ment, dans le domaine de lâ€™environnement, les externalitÃ©s nÃ©gatives constituent des situations de pollutions, dâ€™altÃ©ration des ressources naturelles, de destruction de paysages, de pertes de biodiversitÃ© et dâ€™autres nuisances environnementales qui affectent le bien-Ãªtre dâ€™individus sans que cette perte ne soit compensÃ©e par un mÃ©canisme marchand. La plupart du temps, les externalitÃ©s environnementales sont des coÃ»ts additionnels pris en charge par les autoritÃ©s publiques (ex : gouvernement, collectivitÃ©s territoriales) et les citoyens. Elles se matÃ©rialisent notamment par la pollution atmosphÃ©rique, les nuisances sonores, les Ã©missions de gaz Ã  effet de serre, la pollution des eaux et des sols, mais Ã©galement par les atteintes Ã  la biodiversitÃ©.
Des Ã©tudes soulignent que les dÃ©cideurs, les dÃ©veloppeurs de produits, les dirigeants dâ€™entreprises, les administrateurs publics ou les consommateurs prendraient des dÃ©cisions diffÃ©rentes sâ€™ils avaient lâ€™information leur permettant dâ€™Ã©valuer plus largement les consÃ©quences environnementales de leurs dÃ©cisions (Bithas, 2011; Hond, 2000; Oâ€™Rourke et al., 1996; Van den Bergh, 2012) ou sâ€™ils devaient Ã©galement payer les prix reflÃ©tant la valeur monÃ©taire des externalitÃ©s de lâ€™utilisation des matiÃ¨res et de lâ€™Ã©nergie. Elles concluent aussi que, fondamentalement, les problÃ¨mes environnementaux sont causÃ©s par les dÃ©faillances de la rÃ©glementation et du marchÃ© qui peuvent Ãªtre corrigÃ©es si les dÃ©cideurs ont la bonne information et sâ€™ils sont exposÃ©s aux bons prix.
De plus, les changements environnementaux sont liÃ©s Ã  des effets de deux natures: leviers indirects et pressions directes. Par leviers indirects, le Millenium Ecosystem Assessment (MEA) (Assessment, 2005) adresse les changements dÃ©mographiques, Ã©conomiques, sociopolitiques, scientifiques et technologiques. Quant aux pressions directes, elles incluent la conversion des sols, la surexploitation des ressources naturelles, lâ€™apport excessif de nutriments, les maladies, les invasions dâ€™espÃ¨ces et le changement climatique. Ces pressions affectent les Ã©cosystÃ¨mes de diffÃ©rentes maniÃ¨res selon les contextes et agissent Ã  travers diffÃ©rentes Ã©chelles organisationnelles, temporelles et spatiales. Les systÃ¨mes industriels sont fortement impliquÃ©s et responsables des pressions quâ€™ils exercent sur la biodiversitÃ© et les services Ã©cosystÃ©miques. Le MEA a identifiÃ© six dÃ©fis majeurs concernant directement les impacts des activitÃ©s industrielles :la raretÃ© de lâ€™eau douce, le changement climatique, les changements dâ€™habitat, les espÃ¨ces invasives, la surexploitation des ocÃ©ans et la surcharge de nutriments. Ces derniers peuvent conduire Ã  des dÃ©pendances qui varient en fonction des secteurs dâ€™activitÃ©s et au sein mÃªme dâ€™un mÃªme secteur, selon la technologie employÃ©e et du contexte de lâ€™activitÃ© de production ou de consommation *.
*Les systÃ¨mes industriels impactent de faÃ§on directe lâ€™Ã©cosystÃ¨me, notamment en occupant les sols avec leurs Ã©quipements de production et par la pollution rÃ©sultant des processus de production. Ils impactent aussi de maniÃ¨re indirecte par lâ€™intermÃ©diaire de leurs fournisseurs de matiÃ¨res premiÃ¨res ou de produits semi-finis, ainsi que par les usages et fin de vie engendrÃ©s. MÃªme si certaines entreprises considÃ¨rent ces liens comme des contraintes, les prendre en compte peut permettre de mieux apprÃ©hender les risques et dâ€™identifier des opportunitÃ©s
Par ailleurs, la prise en compte des services Ã©cosystÃ©miques peut prÃ©senter de nouvelles opportunitÃ©s pour les entreprises, comme favoriser lâ€™Ã©mergence de nouvelles technologies et de nouveaux produits permettant de rÃ©duire la dÃ©gradation, de restaurer les Ã©cosystÃ¨mes ou dâ€™augmenter lâ€™efficacitÃ© dans lâ€™utilisation des services Ã©cosystÃ©miques. Cela peut aussi permettre lâ€™obtention de nouvelles parts de marchÃ© grÃ¢ce au lancement dâ€™un nouveau produit ou service Ã  faible impact sur les Ã©cosystÃ¨mes, donc disposant dâ€™une Ã©co-labellisation. Au niveau de la rÃ©glementation, on peut noter lâ€™engagement du gouvernement, concrÃ©tisÃ© notamment par la StratÃ©gie Nationale pour la BiodiversitÃ© (SNB), pour dÃ©velopper des politiques favorables Ã  la conservation des Ã©cosystÃ¨mes ou des incitations visant Ã  protÃ©ger ou restaurer des Ã©cosystÃ¨mes qui fournissent des services. Lâ€™intÃ©gration de cette relation impacts/dÃ©pendances au niveau des systÃ¨mes dâ€™information permettrait dâ€™avoir une autre vision des entreprises au regard de leurs activitÃ©s industrielles.
